Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not follow up with or provide supportive assistance
to the foster family related to the foster child's negative and
aggressive behaviors.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent B
On 1/10/2023 I interviewed Foster Parent B/the complainant by
telephone. Foster Parent B reported Child A was placed in her
home from 10/13/2022 until 1/6/2023. The agency told her this
was Child A’s first time coming into care, and he had no behavior
2

concerns. Foster Parent B reported when she and her husband
began to notice behavior issues with Child A, they began reporting
the behavior concerns to the agency. The agency worker and
supervisor were not responsive to their concerns. She said she
began reaching out to Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) 3 because
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4 was not following up with her. She
said the agency did not return emails in a timely manner, and
when Child A became a threat to her family and himself, the
agency did not respond timely to remove him. She reported the
agency staff’s actions/lack of action was disrespectful to her.
Foster Parent B said Child A had episodes of crying since first
being placed in her home. She said it was in December 2022
when Child A’s behavior escalated and got more aggressive. She
reported the behaviors that Child A displayed were that he was
combative (no details reported), he had multiple screaming spells,
and he pushed her. She reported the first time Child A “became
physically aggressive and put hands on me” was in December
2022. Foster Parent B did not elaborate on what she meant by
putting hands on her, but she had stated prior that Child A pushed
her. Foster Parent B did not describe the type of push or the
circumstances around it.
Foster Parent B said she wanted to get Child A in therapy but
knew that takes time. She said, Child A had an intake mental
health service appointment on 12/7/2022 which the agency was
aware of. She said a mental health appointment was set, but it
was cancelled after she requested Child A’s replacement later in
December of 2022. She said when she would ask FCW 4 for
resources to assist Child A and her family, FCW 4 did not provide
suggestions of things they could do related to Child A’s behaviors.
She said FCW 4’s standard statement was that “this is what you
signed up for”. She said she told FCW 4 that she was not asking
him to take Child A for the appointment, just for him to provide
resources. She said FCW 4 told her she could contact him for
assistance, gave her his telephone number, but he was not sure
of what to do. He told her he would speak with his supervisor and
would get back with her. Foster Parent B could not recall whether
FCW 4 called her back. Foster Parent B said FCW 4 did finally
provide some resources, but then Child A’s became physically
aggressive, and she and her husband requested Child A’s
emergency removal. She said the agency responded to their
request by saying the agency has 30-days to replace Child A.
She said she sent the agency emails about Child A’s behaviors
and her’s and her husband’s request for Child A’s removal. She
said there was minimal communication from the agency about
3

their request. She provided me a copy of three emails she sent
the agency inclusive of a 12/17/2022 email from her to FCS 3
describing Child A’s behaviors. The email indicated:
➢ Child A is becoming more and more aggressive, displaying
oppositional defiant behavior; having increased screaming
and crying spells. The screaming spells having become
more frequent, occurring several times a day.
➢ Child A blocked one of them from walking down the
stairway and pushed one of them recently.
➢ Child A resists them holding his hand when walking in the
streets and in other public areas and pulls away.
➢ Child A does not follow instructions or timeouts at the home
they do not have any other resources at their disposal to
help de-escalate Child A’s aggressive outbursts and
behavior.
➢ They have tried multiple ways to manage his behavior
including, music therapy, Yoga, breath therapy, toys,
pictures of his loved ones in his room, reading stories about
emotions, exercise, play therapy, teaching him proper
reactions and emotion control with a puppy, singing,
attempted water therapy for relaxation, contacting the crisis
center, but Child A’s aggressive and oppositional defiant
behavior is increasing instead of decreasing.
➢ They contacted the crisis center on one occasion due to
Child A’s aggressive behavior and have begun the process
to secure mental health services for Child A.
Foster Parent B admitted a Family Team Meeting (FTM) was
scheduled to discuss her foster home’s request for Child A’s
replacement and examine efforts that might be pursued to
maintain the placement. She reported the agency initially
scheduled the FTM for 1/5/2023 and that was changed to
1/6/2023. She said the agency never acknowledged their request
for the removal, nor offered an assessment of the situation. The
agency only sent the email about the meeting. Foster Parent A
said she did not attend the meeting due to a time frame conflict,
but she asked the agency about the results of that meeting. She
was advised the agency had planned to replace Child A on
1/9/2023. Foster Parent B reported she terminated the placement
on 1/6/2023 by dropping Child A off at the agency’s 13-mile office
(not the agency’s foster care agency) due to “safety concerns.”
She reported not knowing the correct office to take Child A to. She
acknowledged being advised she could not just drop the child off,
and that a children services complaint could be called against her
foster home.
4

Agency Interviews
On 1/30/2023 I interviewed, Licensee Designee 1 Administrator 2,
FCS 3 and FCW 4 onsite site. I also spoke with Licensee
Designee 1 by telephone on 1/10/2023.
Administrator 2
Administrator 2 reported the allegations are not true, saying the
agency was responsive to Foster Parent B emails and phone
calls. She reported per information from the agency staff and
review of the case record, the first time FCW 3 reported a concern
being made by Foster Parent B was on 12/12/2022. The concern
was that Child A throws temper tantrums when Child A does not
get his way. Administrator 2 reported the foster parents were
uncooperative, had high and unrealistic expectations related to a
four-year-old and ended up dumping Child A off at their sister
agency.
Licensee Designee 1
Licensee Designee (LD) 1 reported it was true that Foster Parent
B had reported concerns, but not true that the agency was not
responsive to the family. She agreed with Administrator 2 as to
the first time Foster Parent B reported behavioral concerns for
Child A. LD 1 recalled the concern being something to the effect
of Foster Parent B reporting Foster Parent B and her husband
were afraid to walk down their stairs because Child A would block
the stairway and that scared them. The next time Foster Parent B
contacted the agency was via email on Sunday, 12/18/2022 (the
narrative was dated 12/17/2022, but it was received 12/18/2022),
and that email was responded to on 12/19/2022. LD 1 reported if
there was any type of delay in getting back to Foster Parent B, it
may have been due to it being a holiday, and therefore the
response to Foster Parent B may have occurred the next business
day. LD 1 said with respect to Foster Parent B’s emails wanting
Child A removed, she was also emailed and she responded to
Foster Parent B. The agency advised Foster Parent B the agency
was trying to secure another placement for Child A. Also, that the
Department was also looking for a placement him, but all this was
not fast enough for Foster Parent B.
Foster Care Supervisor 3
FCS 3 reported being the supervisor for Child A’s case since his
placement with the agency. She reported becoming aware of a
behavior reports for Child A within the first week of his placement.
The behavior was related to normal separation and loss, not
aggression. Foster Parent B and her husband said Child A was
crying a lot/having crying spells. Child A was saying he wanted to
5

go back with his mother and siblings. FCW 4 gave the foster
parents resources on therapy and around trauma. FCS 3 reported
knowing the latter was done, because the foster parents sent an
email saying they followed up with a therapy intake. FCS 3 said
she was not sure if the therapy had started before Child A left the
foster home.
FCS 3 acknowledged there came a time she became aware of
more behavioral concerns for Child A. She said during a
supervision with FCW 4 sometime in November 2022, FCW 4 said
Foster Parent B was reporting that Child A was getting out of
control and crying all the time. Foster Parent B was not giving
FCW 4 specifics on what being out of control meant. FCS 3
advised FCW 4 to try to obtain more specifics related to the
behavior from Foster Parent B. For him to also share information
with the family about the foster parent support group, since this
was the foster family’s first placement. FCS 3 said FCW 4 had
already explored the possibility of a Difficult of Care rate (DOC)
exploration, but Foster Parent B didn’t sign the document, and
was getting frustrated with FCW 4 and the process. Additionally,
Child A was not showing qualification for any of the DOC
categories.
FCS 3 denied awareness of Foster Parent B and or her husband
having a fear of Child A’s behavior until a 12/18/2022 email from
Foster Parent B. FCS 3 spoke with FCW 4 but was confused
about what Foster Parent B was reporting as concerns with
extreme behaviors because the behaviors being reported were
ones a child dealing with trauma would present. And Foster
Parent B had made contact with the crisis line and was referred
for therapy. Also, at that point the foster parents were being
uncooperative, Child A was missing his visit due to that, and the
relationship was deteriorating. The foster family was requesting
Child A’s removal and FCS 3 was not sure what more the agency
was to do other than to seek another placement for Child A
FCS 3 admitted to telling Foster Parent B the agency has 30-days
to find another placement for Child A but she followed up with
Foster Parent B on 12/19/2022 to let Foster Parent B know a
placement was being worked on. After that Foster Parent B kept
emailing saying Child A was constantly crying, and that he tried to
push her down the stairs. She told Foster Parent B several times
no placement was available for Child A, but once one was found
she would contact Foster Parent B. She was in contact with the
foster parent almost daily thereafter. FCS 3 also sought respite for
Child A on 1/3/2023, but their licensing department was unable to
6

find a respite provider. She said the agency sought to find a
replacement home, as soon as possible, but Foster Parent B did
not seem to think they were acting fast enough on anything.
FCS 3 reported prior to the foster parent’s replacement request
the foster parents had only phoned her once and it was not related
to Child A’s behavior. The foster parents had never phoned or
emailed her to voice a concern about FCW 4 or to report FCW 4
was not doing what he was supposed to/what they needed or
requested. No one ever told Foster Parent B this is what she
signed up for. FCW 4 only tried to normalize the behaviors that
Child A was displaying around his loss, but Foster Parent B just
didn’t seem to understand that trauma or to accept Child A’s
behaviors as normal for him in this situation.
Foster Care Worker 4
FCW 4 reported being assigned to Child A’s case since
10/13/2022. He denied the foster parent contacting him all the
time about Child A’s behavior. He denied being disrespectful to
the foster parents in any way or not responding to their contacts.
He reported that the first time behavior concerns for Child A were
brought to his attention was during a foster home visit on
12/12/2022. Foster Parent B reported that Child A was very
emotional, and would cry a lot, especially after Child A’s parenting
time. FCW 4 reminded Foster Parent B Child A was coming into
care with lots of trauma and him crying a lot was to be expected.
Foster Parent B said Child A would cry for hours, he had extreme
behaviors, and he was “out of control”, but Foster Parent B would
not specify what were the out-of-control behaviors. She only said
Child A would stand in front of the stairs blocking their passage.
He asked Foster Parent B whether Child A was hitting, kicking or
biting and Foster Parent B would only state Child A was “out of
control” and that Child A had been that way since Child A first
came into her home. FCW 4 reported on that date, this was the
first time the foster family was saying this. He said he had
previously provided Foster Parent B with therapy resources that
accepted Child A’s insurance. He advised that this is what he
does with all his cases, because of the issues of traumatization.
He encouraged the foster family to follow through on the resource.
He knew Foster Parent B utilized the resource because a
therapeutic intake occurred, and services were pending. He
reminded the foster parent of the resource.
FCW 4 report not being contacted by the foster parents again
about behavior concerns for Child A until 12/18/2022 (a Sunday)
via an email to FCS 3, which he was copied on. At that time
7

Foster Parent B put in a 30-day replacement request. FCW 4
spoke with FCS 3 about that email request on Monday
12/19/2022. FCS 3 advised him she would follow up with the
foster parents, which FCS 3 did via email and copied him on that
day. He said the next time the foster parents referenced Child A’s
behavior was on 1/6/2022. Foster Parent B texted him on that
date to indicate she had dropped Child A off at the Royal Oak
office and that Child A’s behavior was a continued safety concern.
Document Review
Copies of emails from Foster Parent B showing she emailed the
foster care supervisor, worker and or another agency staff and the
agency’s reply:
➢ A 12/18/2023 email dated 12/17/2022 as described in
Foster Parent B interviewed. She requested to have Child
A replaced from her foster home.
➢ A 12/19/2022 email response from FCS 3 to Foster Parent
B. FCS 3 acknowledged the foster parent’s email and
expressed concern about what was being reported by
Foster Parent B. FCS 3 indicated she would notify the
licensing department and they will begin the search to find
a new placement for Child A. That per policy licensing does
have 30 days to find a new placement, but they will begin
the search immediately.
➢ A 12/31/2022 email from Foster Parent B that indicated
Child A is “continuously being combative, pushing and
having screaming spells. He blocked her from walking
down the steps again today. Emergency removal
requested. She asked FCS 3 to please let them know when
the emergency removal will occur. That if FCS 3 is unable
to address this concern, please let them know who they
need to contact.
➢ A 1/6/2023 email to FCS 3 and FCW 4 inquiring whether an
email and text was received related to a summary of the
team meeting which they were not able to attend. That they
are awaiting a response to their request for Child A’s
emergency removal, and that they have not received any
phone calls from the worker since they put in the request.
This email reiterated they have safety concerns and also,
they are looking forward to information regarding when
Child A will be picked up today or what they need to do.
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
➢ Child A entered care due to neglect. He was placed with
the agency on 10/13/2022, and with Foster Parent B and
Foster Parent C on that date.
8

➢ His placement intake indicated he may have asthma. No
other identified special needs were indicated.
➢ Verification of FCW 4 providing the foster family various
therapeutic and daycare resources on 10/25/2022. The
documentation to Foster Parent B denoted that the
resources included a few facilities that can handle trauma
therapy and accepts Medicaid.
➢ Agency contact with Foster Parent B by email on
12/19/2022 acknowledging the removal request. They will
begin a replacement search immediately.
➢ A follow up email from FCS 3 sent in response to another
email from Foster Parent B’s email on 12/19/2022, where
FCS 3 indicated the agency did not have a foster home
lined up yet and would have nowhere to place Child A
today. That time is needed to locate another placement,
and FCS 3 would reach back out to Foster Parent B once
FCS 3 has more information to report.
➢ A 1/3/2023 text to Foster Parent B from FCW 4 about a
possible placement for Child A
➢ A 1/3/2023 email to Foster Parent B by FCS 3 that a
placement was located but the family cannot take Child A
until 1/9/2023. Additionally, following an email from Foster
Parent B that Child A’s behaviors are escalating, and she
cannot wait to have him removed from the home, and she
will not transport him to his parenting time today. FCS 3
advised Foster Parent B she would try to locate a respite
placement for Child A sooner than 1/9/2023, and asked
Foster Parent B whether an alternate caregiver person
could assist Foster Parent B with parenting time transport.
➢ A 1/4/2023 text to Foster Parent B from FCW 4 inviting the
foster parent to an FTM on 1/5/2023 related to Child A
replacement. Foster Parent B replied back she will not
attend the meeting. And later documentation of the FTM on
1/5/2023.
➢ Subsequent back and forth emails/contacts between FCS
FCW 4, or Licensee Designee 1 with Foster Parent B
between 12/21/2023 and 1/6/2023 related to Foster Parent
B’s questions about the status of Child A’s removal plans
and the agency attempts to replace him as soon as
possible.
➢ A 1/5/2023 7:53PM social work contact by centralize intake
that Foster Parent B contacted centralized intake about
getting Child A removed, alleging the agency had not been
responsive to their request for removal, indicating Child A
has kicking, and hitting behaviors (which in prior contacts
9

Foster Parent B had not reported) and that she was
thinking of dropping Child A off.
➢ A 1/6/2023 text from Foster Parent B to FCW 4 that she
dropped Child A off at the Royal Oak Judson Center office.
Then communication by LD 1 with Foster Parent B while
Foster Parent B was at the Royal Oak location, and LD 1
advised Foster Parent B not to leave Child A at the Judson
Child Safe office. Foster Parent B ultimately left Child A at
Judson Child Safe.
` Based on interviews and case information documented, there is
insufficient evidence to support the allegation that the agency was
not responding to the foster parent’s requests for assistance and
the child’s replacement. Nor sufficient evidence of a lack of direct
work with relevant individuals related to implementation of the
case service plan.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12411 Clothing policy.
Section (1) An agency’s clothing policy shall, at a minimum, ensure that
Description each foster child has a sufficient amount of clothing that is
appropriate as to size and season and that is in good repair.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not provide a clothing allowance to the foster
parents for the foster child.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Parent B
On 1/10/2023 I interviewed Foster Parent B/the complainant by
telephone. Foster Parent B reported Child A was brought to her
home with inadequate clothing. He had inappropriate under
clothing, a pair of plastic shoes, and a thin coat. She said she
spoke with the worker about a clothing allowance for him on a
number of occasions, but she was never given an update on the
status of the clothing allowance. She sent an email to the agency
as recent 1/5/2023. She provided me a copy of that email that
listed an outstanding $210.00 clothing allowance. Foster Parent B
did not say she had not purchased clothing for Child A, only that
she never received the clothing allowance.
Agency Interviews
10

On 1/30/2023 I interviewed Licensee Designee 1, Administrator 2,
FCS 3, and FCW 4 onsite site. I also spoke with Licensee
Designee 1 by telephone on 1/10/2023.
Licensee Designee 1 and Administrator 2
These administrators reported Child A was not without clothing.
They said Child A’s clothing allowance was delayed and was
pending. Neither reported the reason for the delay.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)3
FCS 3 did not recall speaking with Foster Parent B about a
clothing allowance. She reported the process for the clothing
allowance request is for the worker to complete a clothing
inventory (DHS-3377) and submit it to her so that the clothing
allowance can be submitted to the State. She said FCW 4
completed the DHS-3377 form timely on his first foster home visit
in October 2022, but FCW 4 did not submit the form to her, so that
the clothing allowance request could occur. FCW 4 apparently
forgot. He did not submit the October DHS-3377 to her until about
one week ago.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)4
FCW 4 affirmed FCS 3’s reporting. He said he completed the
clothing inventory on 10/18/2022 and Foster Parent B signed it
that day. He acknowledged that Child A only came with a few
items, and some were not adequate. He explained to Foster
Parent B it was not abnormal for children to enter care that way.
He informed Foster Parent B he would submit the clothing
allowance request but did not give her a timeline as to when the
funds would be available. She also advised Foster Parent B of
the agency’s foster care clothing closet, but Foster Parent B never
followed up to utilize it. He also told Foster Parent B, he could
pick up Child A some items from the foster care clothing closet,
but he was never provided Child A’s sizes by Foster Parent B. He
said he could not have just taken items to provide to the family,
because they had not indicated the sizes on the DHS-3377, he
completed on 10/18/2022.
FCW 4 said he uploaded the DHS-3377 form into their shared
folder and thought FCS 3 would go in and see it. He admitted the
protocol is that they are to notify the supervisor that the DHS-3377
is in the system and to provide the supervisor a copy of the
document. He admitted to not submitting the October inventory to
FCS 3 until a about a week ago. He could not recall the exact date
of that submission but stated the clothing allowance for Child A
was pending. He reported this delay did not mean Child A did not
11

having clothing. He said Child A received clothing via the holiday
wish list. FCW 4 said he did not complete a new clothing
inventory/DHS-3377 for Child A’s new placement. Child A’s
clothing allowance will be provided to his new placement.
Document Review
• Clothing Inventory (DHS-3377) date 10/18/2022 which
showed he had one jacket, one pajamas, and one hat. His
shoe size was written on form as a “size 13 or 1”. No other
sizes were noted.
• Judson Center’s Clothing policy outlining the process for
ensuring children receive clothing in a timely matter that is
in good repair and sufficient and appropriate to size and
season.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support that Child A did not have
clothing to meet his needs after being in placement with Foster
Parent B and Foster Parent C; only that the foster parents did not
receive the clothing allowance. Child A received clothing via the
agency’s holiday drive, and clothing were also offered via the
agency’s foster care clothing closet, if needed, and that was not
utilized by the foster family.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12403 Policy and procedures
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the foster care services provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency reported it would reimburse the foster parents for the
child’s day care registration fee of $100 and has not done so.
Interviews:
Foster Parent B
On 1/10/2023 I interviewed Foster Parent B/the complainant by
telephone. Foster Parent B reported having to paid a $100.00
registration fee to enroll Child A in Daycare in November 2022.
She provided the receipt to FCW 4, who said he would get the fee
reimbursed. He never said how long that would take, but the
agency has not reimbursed her.
Foster Parent B provided me an email dated 1/5/2023 that she
sent to FCW 4, FCS 3 and LD 1. The email indicated mileage
sheet totals for October, November and December 2022 were
enclosed and that other outstanding items for reimbursement
included the registration at KinderCare for $100.
12

Agency Interviews
On 1/30/2023 I interviewed, Licensee Designee 1; FCS 3 and
FCW 4 about this complaint onsite. I also spoke with Licensee
Designee 1 by telephone on 1/10/2023. All three staff denied
telling Foster Parent B the agency would reimburse the fee.
Licensee Designee (LD) 1
LD 1 said she spoke with Foster Parent B in late October or early
November about swimming lessons for Child A, which the agency
helped get Child A into. Foster Parent B never mentioned a
registration fee back in. LD 1 acknowledged Foster Parent B had
mentioned a Daycare registration fee via email on 1/6/2023 when
Foster Parent B submitted mileage documentation for
reimbursement. She told Foster Parent B she would follow up on
that. Then everything blew up with Foster Parent B dropping Child
A off; and she forgot to response back, but she never told her the
agency would pay the fee.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)3
FCS 3 did not recall ever telling Foster Parent B the agency would
reimburse her for a daycare fee.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4
FCW 4 reported Foster Parent B had initially told him about the
total cost for the day care was over a $1000,00 and he advised
her that the agency does not have those resources. He told her
day care payments are covered via the State and gave her the link
via email on 10/25/2022. He said Foster Parent B never
mentioned a $100.00 registration fee to him prior; he was not sure
why Foster Parent B thought he said the agency would pay a
daycare fee.
Document Review
• A 1/6/2023 email from Foster Parent B to FCW 3, FCS 4
and LD 1 which contained information as described earlier
in this section.
• A 10/25/2022 email by FCW 4 referenced in his interview
showing information regarding day care assistance and
therapeutic resources.
• Child A’s Initial Service Plan (ISP) showing a 10/21/2022
contact where Foster Parent B reported to FCW 4 she has
found a private school she wants Child A to attend and
FCW 4 advised her children in foster care do not typically
have coverage for private school.
13

• A 10/27/2022 contact within that ISP that indicated Foster
Parent B contacted FCW 4 about assistance with daycare
coverage, daycare facilities and therapy locations and the
worker had emailed Foster Parent B with all resources and
Foster Parent B confirmed receipt of the resources.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed there is
insufficient evidence to support the allegation or that foster care
services were not provided.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the foster care services provided.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least the following
areas:
(d) Clothing
Violation Additional Finding
Type
Allegation Child A’s clothing allowance was delayed when the agency did not
follow its clothing policy.
Investigation Interviews:
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)3
During FCS 3’s interview on 1/30/2023 she reported the process
for the clothing allowance request is for the worker to complete a
clothing inventory (DHS-3377) and submit it to her so that the
clothing allowance can be submitted. She said FCW 4 completed
the DHS-377 form timely on his first foster home visit in October
2022, but FCW 4 did not submit the form to her so that the
clothing request could occur. FCW 4 did not submit the DHS-3377
to her until about one week ago.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) 4
FCW 4 affirmed FCS 3’s reporting. FCW 4 reported he did not
complete a new DHS-3377 after Child A’s replacement from
Foster Parent B’s home.
Document Review
• MISACWIS documentation provided by the agency
showing the service authorization for Child A’s clothing
allowance was routing through this system on 1/24/2023,
and approval was pending.
• Judson Center’s Clothing Policy which indicated in addition
to the FCW completing the clothing inventory with the foster
14

parent and signing it along with the foster parent, the FCW
is to do the following:
➢ Attempt to obtain clothing from the parent if this is
the child’s initial placement into foster care. If
clothing cannot be obtained from the parent/family or
does not meet the needs of the child based on the
DHS-3377 Clothing Inventory, initial clothing monies
will be requested from DHHS.
➢ Upload a copy of the completed clothing inventory
into MISACWIS for requesting initial clothing monies.
➢ Maintain a copy of the form in the case file and
submit to the program billing support staff.
➢ Meet monthly with the foster parent and child and
assess the child’s needs, including clothing.
➢ Ensure that a clothing inventory has been completed
and signed when children have a placement
changed or return home.
Analysis The agency did not follow all aspects of its policy as outlined and
Child A’s initial clothing allowance request and approval was
delayed. Additionally, FCW 4 did not complete a new DHS-3377
after Child A’s replacement from Foster Parent B’s and Foster C’s
home, as required by agency policy.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current licensing status is recommended.
